title: there no hope prime minister
story: There is no hope for mocked and ridiculed Prime Minister who leads by the fringeI never bought the Johnson appeal but I understood why many voters did - now his political obituaries are being written, writes Kevin MaguireThe despised Downing St party liar Boris Johnson’s authority has gone for good Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsMercilessly mocked and ridiculed, the despised Downing St party liar Boris Johnson’s authority has gone for good. No Prime Minister is able to survive for long in high office when they trigger scorn in every home, workplace, cafe and pub. A mate of mine, a retired welder in a red wall seat, sent a reworking of a joke about a dead man at the Pearly Gates and was informed by St Peter the hands on heavenly lie clocks ticked only when fibs were heard. The pointers on those of Mother Theresa, Abraham Lincoln and Nelson Mandela had never moved. “Where’s Boris Johnson’s clock ” inquired the man. “We’re using it as a ceiling fan,” replied St Peter. Sacricing the jobs of Downing Street staff to save his own skin will not work for Johnson. It feels like when nothe is booted out of No  by Tory MPs worried about their futures. Nor is he able to cower in a fridge again as the glass door on the front of No ’s wine-time Friday cooler symbolises the charlatan having hidden in plain sight for too long.  Suitcases of booze smuggled into Downing Street, drunken shenanigans on the eve of the Duke of Edinburgh’s funeral and an unprecedented apology to Buckingham Palace have a last days of Rome vibe to them. Labour leads of up to % in the polls are encouraging the opposition to go for the jugular, Keir Starmer justiably accusing the PM of breaking the law and lying. With jilted insider Dominic Cummings orchestrating much of the onslaught, there’s an irony in Johnson as co-author of his own downfall. Labour is aware it should target the Tories as much as Johnson himself when as rising star Wes Streeting acknowledged, the opposition’s best bet’s a mortally wounded PM limping on or the Conservatives will claim they have changed under Rishi Sunak or Liz Truss.What do you think  Have your say in the comments below.From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  They successfully played the trick in Government when John Major succeeded Margaret Thatcher, Theresa May followed David Cameron then Johnson came after May. I never bought the Johnson appeal but I understood why many voters did. Brexit, his main pitch, was another lie and anyway even many who wanted to quit the European Union these days avoid talking about the mess. Whatever magic Johnson displayed is gone and isn’t ing. The steady drip of awful rule-breaking, civil servant Sue Gray’s party report, April’s tax rises and soaring energy bills and May’s local elections all threaten fresh blows for a deflated egotist who cut a beaten figure on the ropes at Prime Minister’s Questions. Lting England’s Covid restrictions will earn little credit when he’s lost credibility. Johnson’s political obituaries are being written. Only the publication date is to be decided. History will be justiably unkind to a truly terrible leader. title: what pork pie plot dozens
story: What is the Pork Pie Plot as dozens of Tory MPs turn on Boris Johnson over PartygateScores of Tory MPs from the  intake have turned on Boris Johnson over Partygate. Heres what you need to know about the Pork Pie Plot as MPs conspire over Johnsons futureBoris Johnson could soon be facing a vote of confidence from his MPs Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan | commentsBoris Johnsonaposs premiership is at risk like never before as over a dozen Tory MPs from the  election are said to be furious at the Prime Minister for his handling of the Partygate scandal.The MPs are reportedly preparing to submit their letters of no confidence to the chairman of the  Committee of backbench MPs, Sir Graham Brady - and some are believed to have already written in.Reports suggest that the  letters will reach Sir Graham by Wednesday, January , which means Johnson could be facing a vote of no confidence soon after.Hereaposs everything you need to know about the conspiratorial aposPork Pie Plotapos, which Tory MPs have publicly called for the Prime Minister to resign and whataposs likely to happen next.What is the Pork Pie Plot about  More than  Tory MPs who won seats in the ‘Red Wall’ - a number of constituencies in northern England that had typically voted Labour until the  election - are said to have met on Tuesday, January  to discuss Johnsonaposs future as Prime Minister.The gathering was nicknamed the “Pork Pie Plot” or the “Pork Pie Putsch” as it was hosted by MP for Rutland and Melton Alicia Kearns - and Melton is the town best known for its pork pies. Some of the plotters include Bishop Auckland MP Dehenna Davison Chris Loder, who hosted the group’s last meeting Gary Sambrook , the first Tory to hold Birmingham Northfield since , as well as Bury South MP Christian Wakeford, who is best-known for cursing at scandal-hit colleague Owen Paterson in the Commons.Who has called for the Prime Minister to resign  Seven Tory MPs have publicly called for Johnsonaposs resignation. Wakeford – who has a majority of just  – was the latest to make the call for the Prime Minister to resign on Tuesday. He then defected to Labour just before Wednesdayaposs Prime Ministeraposs Questions, citing Johnson as incapable of offering the leadership and government this country deserves. Though only a handful of Tories have publicly called for his resignation, several of them are believed to be furious over Johnsonaposs handling of the Partygate scandal. They were angered further by the PMaposs statement that nobody told him that the party at Downing Street was a violation of the country-wide rules he himself had set.Whataposs likely to happen next  An inquiry into the Downing Street parties, led by senior civil servant Sue Gray, is expected to be published on either Friday or early next week.Some MPs are reported to be waiting for Ms Gray’s findings before deciding on submitting a letter to Sir Graham. If the  letters needed to trigger a no confidence vote is reached, the next step will see Tory MPs voting on whether they have confidence in in the Prime Minister. Johnson will need % or more of MPs to back him or end up losing his position. If he does end up winning, then the MPs will be barred from forcing another vote on his premiership for the next  months. news uk-news covid-lateral-flow-tests-less-"Covid restrictions may be ‘substantially’ reduced next week says JavidByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsCovid lateral flow tests don’t work as well on children, according to a new study.A team of British and German scientists have pooled together results from  old studies, involving over , kids, to examine the efficacy of lateral flows in detecting Covid amongst young people. Writing in the British Medical Journal, their study claims that the rapid kits were not as effective in youngsters and students, even as all secondary school students in Britain are encouraged to use them twice weekly. Their findings said that the tests only detected  per cent of Covid positive children. When the children had symptoms of Covid, like a cough or change or loss to the sense of taste and smell, detection rates increased to  per cent.  This means only little over half the youngsters who had the virus were caught. The authors said their findings meant that lateral flow tests would fail to meet the minimum standards of the UK’s Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, the US’ Food and Drug Administration and the World Health Organisation. These three bodies all require Covid testing kits to meet a minimum of around an  per cent success rate.  The study only included samples taken by professionally trained iniduals and not self testing at home.This comes as Omicron cases continue to fall, day-on-day, amidst hopes the fourth waves has peaked.One of the authors, Dr Naomi Fujita-Rohwerder, of the Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care in Cologne, Germany, said: “Taking into account test-specic pooled results, no test included in this review fully satisfied the minimum performance requirements as recommended by WHO...the US…or the MHRA in the UK.  “This may affect the planned purpose of the broad implementation of testing programmes.” The report only examined studies that used eight dferent lateral flow kits, so some of the + tests available globally may be more accurate. All of the studie looked at in the new analysis were published between the start of  and May  meaning they will not have contained the Omicron iant.  The researchers did not offer any reasons why the tests had performed less accurately on children, or a comparative study in adults. Regular and freely available lateral flow tests are a key part of the UK’s response to Covid and containing it. story: Covid vaccine near me: Postcode checker shows your nearest siteGoogle is encouraging people to get their Covid vaccinations done in its latest Google Doogle. The postcode checker below will let you find your nearest site easilyBrits are being encouraged to get the Covid vaccine Image: Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Jan | commentsTodayaposs Google Doodle is encouraging everyone to wear a mask and get a vaccine.Click on the Google logo and youaposll be taken straight to search results where you can find your nearest Covid vaccination centre. More than  million doses of the coronavirus vaccine have been given in the UK, with more than  million people double-vaccinated. However, plenty remain unvaccinated – so you should book and get your Covid vaccine, especially as the Omicron iant continues to spread. Getting a Covid vaccine is incredibly important, as it will reduce the chance of you suffering from Covid- disease, says the government website.It continues: It may take a few weeks for your body to build up some protection from the vaccine. You should get good protection from the first dose.Having a second dose should give you longer lasting protection. A third booster dose of the vaccine is now also needed to ensure optimal protection, helping to give you longer-term protection against getting seriously ill from Covid-. How to find Covid vaccine near you You can use our handy postcode checker to find out where the vaccine is being administered near you. To find your local vaccination centre, all you have to do is enter your postcode in the box below, to view the closest vaccination centres to you.  You can also use the NHS website to find a walk-in coronavirus vaccination site.You donapost need to be registered with a GP to use a walk-in centre.Alternatively you can use the NHS website to book a Covid vaccine.Who can get a Covid vaccine  Anyone over the age of  is entitled to get three Covid jabs. Meanwhile, those aged  to  are currently only able to get two doses. As of December , anyone aged over  can get a booster vaccine. From April , vaccination will be compulsory for all healthcare workers. What are the side effects of the Covid vaccine   The Covid vaccines that are used in the UK have been approved for use, and meet strict standard of safety, quality and effectiveness. However, as with most vaccines, side effects may occur. Any side effects are mild, and should not last longer than a week, says the NHS. Side effects include:a sore arm from the injection feeling tired a headache feeling achy feeling or being sickMore serious side effects such as allergic reactions or blood clotting are very rare. title: extraordinary story britains anne frank
story: Extraordinary story of Britains Anne Frank hidden behind trap doors from Nazis in UKPhyliss Emily Le Breton and her husband John kept Tom hidden away behind trap doors after he managed to flee his German captors during the Nazi regimeTom was the Ukrainian prisoner of war whom the Le Bretons housed and fed Image: Carolyn Horn   SWNSByAdam AspinallNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A family has revealed the extraordinary story of aposBritainaposs Anne Frank apos who hid from the Nazis in their home - and even kept a diary.Phyliss Emily Le Breton and her husband John kept aposTomapos hidden away behind trap doors after he managed to flee his German captors. Tom - real name Bokejon Akram - was a Russian soldier and school teacher taken as a POW by the Third Reich. They took him to the occupied Channel Island of Jersey as a slave but he managed to escape and was taken in by Phyliss and John. They risked their lives by hiding him in their house where he had trap door escape routes.Have your say on this story in the comment section He told their five young kids fairy stories and even kept a diary - just like the teenage Anne Frank in Amsterdam. The family called him aposTomapos and taught him English – partly by reading the Bible with him. He survived with them for three years and was repatriated to the Ukraine in  by the British. They lost touch after the war and the familyaposs story has now emerged as officials at Jersey Heritage try to discover more about him. Phyliss and Emilyaposs grand-daughter Carolyn Horn, , said she was immensely proud of what her family risked to save Tomaposs le. Carolyn, who lives in Cyprus with her husband and three children, said: He became a member of the family. aposaposMy aunt said she called him her favourite uncle, as that was how he was known - Uncle Tom. My grandmother used to talk about Tom all the time. It just shows what kind people they were. It makes me proud.  It was a time of crisis and they had German soldiers walking in whenever. aposaposThey still risked their own lives, and the lives of their children, to help someone who they didnapost even know and let live in their house as a member of their family. There was a little door under the staircase in the house with a trap door behind it - that is how Tom could get from one side of the house to the other.aposapos Phyliss and John are reported to have said: We trusted this man, he was the sort of man we could trust. The children loved him and, when he could understand some English, he used to read them fairy stories. Tomaposs journey began in July  when the young Ukrainian soldier and unmarried school teacher defended his country against German attack. During a two hour period , of his colleagues died and Tom alongside many other Ukrainians became a PoW. The German soldiers collected thousands of people and used them as slave labourers to quarry stone and build coastal defences.  Tom then found himself with , others taken to St Malo in Jersey in July . He was put into hard labour but managed to run away and was found in St Mary - by Phyliss, John, and their four very young children. They were nervous and so renamed Bokejon as Tom to reduce the risk of discoverytheir kids said anything.  Tom slept in in the stables behind a trap door, in a car hidden behind bales of straw and in a shed in case the Germans called. Phylissaposs daughter Dulcie, now in her s, remembers him reading fairy stories to the children and playing with them. Dulcie, who was four when the Occupation began, remembers Tom like a favourite uncle. In May , before repatriation to the Ukraine by British forces, Tom promised to keep in contact.  Three letters arrived in June  from Guernsey where Tom was last known to be - but then nothing. Years later John was one of  Jersey men and women awarded a gold watch by the Soviet government for their courage in helping to shelter Russian and Ukrainian escapees. Historians at Jersey Heritage have now issued a plea for anyone to come forward with more information about him. Chris Addy, sites curator, said they were surprised how much they had been able to find out about them.He said: It’s always a bit of a guess. You never know what stories are going to come out after  years.It’s always fascinating to hear a new piece of information or research, and add it to the stories that we tell each year to remind people about this signicant part of the Island’s history.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Uncle TomAnne FrankEducationSoldiersNazis" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: grieving pensioner left cashless after
story: Exclusive: Grieving pensioner left cashless after computer glitch shuts down her bank accountsJacqueline Sievewright has had to borrow money from her elderly mother after Halax shut down all of her bank accounts and cancelled all of her credit and debit cards following the death of her husbandJacqueline Sievewright was suddenly left cashless Image: Ben Lack Photography LtdByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA grieving pensioner has been left cashless and feeling suicidal after all her bank accounts were closed mysteriously. In the days after Christmas, Jacqueline Sievewright discovered that all her debit and credit cards were no longer working and that she didnapost have a ing bank account. The baffled -year-old borrowed money from her -year-old mum before getting hold of someone at Halax, which sheaposd banked with for years. An operator told her her both her inidual and joint accounts had been closed due to a computer glitch following the death of her husband Francis, who died of pancreatic cancer in October. Despite spending days frantically trying to sort out the issue, cash transfers and direct debits are still bouncing off of Jacquelineaposs frozen accounts. They blocked everything. My credit card, direct debits, standing orders, state pension and private pension was rejected, and money coming in, the Immingham, Lincolnshire woman told the Mirror. I am still grieving. Last Thursday everything just got on top of me. For two days I just cried and cried. I was so low I felt like ending it all. Jacqueline first knew something was amiss the week after Christmas, when her mumaposs attempts to transfer money into her bank account failed. When the former Norfolk County Council worker tried to log in to her online account, it told her she wasnapost registered. She called Halax where an operator explained that the issue was not due to a human error, but a computer glitch. Jacqueline then embarked on several days of calling the bank and sending in her husbandaposs death certicate in a fruitless bid to get the accounts brought back online. She later received a call from Halax telling her requesting a money from a branch would be pointless and that her complaint, despite being unresolved, had been closed internally. I canapost just rely on my -year-old mum for money, Jacqueline said. I spent two days from am to pm ringing round  dferent companies resetting direct debits and informing them of the change of circumstances. I then reinstated two dormant accounts with Natwest and HSBC so I could do some shopping. Two weeks on, Jacquelineaposs accounts have suddenly been reinstated by Halax, which sent her flowers as an apology. The confusing situation has been particularly dficult for Jacqueline as she recently lost her husband Francis. The retired banker fell ill in February last year and was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. In the eight months before he died in October, he spent five and a half in hospital. Jacqueline was able to bring him home from hospital to be with her in his final days. A Lloyds Bank spokesperson said: “We were so sorry to hear of Mrs Sievewright’s loss and the experience she had when she got in touch. Mrs Sievewright’s accounts are up and running again, we’ve provided training and feedback to our team, and we’ll be getting in touch with her to put things right.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NatWestHalax Inc.HSBCBanksHospitalsPensionsCredit cardsState pensionComputers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Kate Middleton wears £ earrings on her and Williams first royal outing of the yearKate and Wills spoke with charity bosses at the Foundling Museum who discussed homelessness, mental health impact and helping young people in care who fail or slip through the cracksPrince William and his we Kate Middleton were seen on their first royal outing of the year as they visited children in care Image: UK Press via Getty ImagesByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Jan | comments The Duchess of Cambridge was joined by husband William for their first royal outing of the year to hear of the challenges of those who turned their lives around after growing up in chaotic homes.Kateaposs stylish budget look included a Jigsaw coat  subtle earrings which cost just £.Kate, who last year set up her Centre for Early Childhood, and Wills spoke with charity bosses at the Foundling Museum who discussed homelessness, mental health impact and helping young people in care who fail or slip through the cracks.The museum which tells the history of the Foundling Hospital, the UKaposs first childrenaposs charity founded in , as a home for children whose mothers couldn’t keep or care for them. Taking their seats, Kate, , who arrived in a smart navy coat and a black polo neck for the engagement in central London, asked the experts: From your experience what makes the dference between a young person succeeding after leaving foster care and when they do not. They heard about challenges for young people when they regularly move home and are sometimes exploited by the criminal world. William added: If you keep moving a child around when they are an adult their relationships are so short and shallow. Kate said she was concerned that without providing stable homes for children they risk being moved around and having to tell their story again and again. Will said: That may become emotionally exhausting to tell the story again and again. Weaposve had that in the mental health side of things, people end up on the street, go through hoops and hurdles, tell so many people in authority and nothing changes. You have to get to them a lot earlier so they donapost have to keep doing this. Later as they left the event William, , could not avoid the drama of his own family as a TV crew asked the Duke do you support Prince Andrew  as the couple left the museum. The Duke leaned closer to hear but then walked past without commenting. Part of their engagement, handpicked by the couple to be their first event of the year, saw them discuss the worry about the consistency in care:  Olympic hero runner Kris Akabusi, poet Lemn Sissay, and Allan Jenkins, editor of Observer Food Monthly, told the Duke and Duchess their experiences of growing up in care. Akabusi said: I enjoyed the stability. It was a saviour for me. He said leaving care aged -years-old was very traumatic. Kate replied: You are petried leaving for independence. She asked the m hurdlerit had affected his relationships. Kris, with his distinctive laugh, replied: Yes, but I am a loner. He added: Now aged  there is no stigma attached when I say I was brought up in care but there was a stigma when I was . Women who had previously been in care then joined the couple in an aposice-breakerapos armed with three-foot long pencils. They drew on a canvas what they could see in front of them without looking down at the floor. Kate - who scored a master of arts degree in art history at St Andrews University - laughed out as she struggled with the artwork which had the look of a vast doodle when it was finished. Duke laughed and said: I enjoyed it. The kids would really enjoy that. Viewing their masterpiece, he added: Thataposs beautul. Athlete Kris Akabusi said afterwards: It is great to have so many vital resources for young people. As a young person in care, to know people at the top are interested in your story and growth as an adult is very encouraging. Hopefully they are not forgotten. Young people who were in care are over-represented in gangs, sex industry and crime, I hope society has not forgotten them as these children are in care throigh no fault of their ownnso it is great to have this infrastructure. The Foundling Museum tells the history of the Foundling Hospital, the UK’s first children’s charity. It was founded in  as a home for children whose mothers couldn’t keep or care for them. The Museum delivers training, mentorship programmes and creative projects, led and developed by contemporary artists, writers and musicians, to continue to use creative action to transform and improve the lives of care-experienced young people. It helps around  adults who grew up in care every year. The Tracing Our Tales is described as a unique programme which has been developed to equip care-experienced young adults from London boroughs with the skills to devise and deliver workshops at the Museum for family groups. The programme provides paid employment and valuable le skills, including public speaking, critical and creative thinking, and people management, as well as skills in art and creative expression. story: Man claims Holiday Inn hotel had dirty clothes behind bed and decomposing food on floorHoliday Inn admits there was a clear lapse in standards after David Craig was disgusted by the state of his hotel room and feared it had not been cleaned for some timeThe Holiday Inn Express in InvernessByJon BradyReporterGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA man was appalled at what he claims was the state of his Holiday Inn hotel room which contained decomposing food on the floor, dust and an item of dirty clothing behind the bed.David Craig wanted to catch up with pals and booked into for an overnight stay at the Holiday Inn Express but he was disgusted after he made the gross discovery behind the bed in his room, the Daily Record reports.The -year-old mechanic found what he says were a dirty pair of womenaposs underwear after he moved the bed to retrieve his car keys. Decomposing bits of food were also strewn across the floor in addition to a layer of dust which suggested it hadnapost been cleaned for some time, David claims.He says hotel staff were apologetic but he worries rooms are not being deep cleaned amidst the Covid- pandemic. David told the Record: We booked a few nights away in Inverness to see some old friends and on the morning of January  I dropped my keys down the back of the bed, where the headboard is. I pulled the bed out and there was a dirty pair of ladiesapos underwear and there was also bits of food and a disgusting amount of dust. You could see it clearly hadnapost been touched in a while. We certainly didnapost expect a room like this, especially with the virus going round. The website of the hotel in Inverness, Scotland, promises daily housekeeping as part of its services.  And a statement from parent company IHG on the webpage promises: IHG has a long-standing commitment to rigorous cleaning procedures. However, David remains concerned that hotels arenapost giving rooms a proper clean in between guests. He added: The hotel staff were apologetic and switched our room and let us stay for nothing. That doesnapost bother us but people need to know whataposs going on in hotels. That area of the room has just totally been ignored. If it had been lovely and clean behind the bed and we found a pair of underwear you would think it might be a one-off. But it was clear the bed hadnapost been moved for a while. It ruined the rest of our stay. Youaposd expect to find the room completely clean, especially now.. A spokesman for the Holiday Inn Express said: Overall, the Holiday Inn Express Inverness has an excellent record for cleanliness however on this occasion there was a clear lapse in standards. The hotel apologised to the guest regarding this matter, which was immediately rectied directly with the guest. news uk-news omicron-cold--simple-steps-"Doctor gives tips to relieve covid- omicron symptomsByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Jan | comments As the winter weather continues and temperatures plummet, many of us are falling ill to seasonal illnesses. With many of the symptoms of the Omicron Covid iant similar to a cold, it can be hard for Brits to know the dference.The symptoms of the new iant are slightly dferent from others such as Delta, and it’s incredibly important to get tested, especially as they can be mild.The most common symptoms we associate with coronavirus is a new continuous cough, a fever and a loss of taste and smell, according to the official list on the NHS website.But with Omicron people are being warned to be vigilant of other classic cold symptoms, such as headaches, sore throats and sneezing.Professor Spector from the ZOE Covid app said data suggests about half of all cases of Delta are being missed because people are only on the lookout for the “classic” Covid symptoms. Do I have Omicron or a cold  The Omicron iant has many symptoms that are similar to the common cold. According to ZOE data scientists, the top five symptoms of Omicron are:Runny nose Headache FatigueSneezingSore throat  According to the NHS, the most common cold symptoms are:A blocked or runny nose A sore throat Headaches Coughs Sneezing A raised temperature Pressure in your ears and face Loss of taste and smellWith many of the symptoms overlapping, there is no guaranteed way to tell the dference without a test.Professor Spector said: For most people, an Omicron positive case will feel much more like the common cold, starting with a sore throat, runny nose and a headache.You only need to ask a friend who has recently tested positive to find this out. We need to change public messaging urgently to save lives.The safest thing to do, and the only way to know for sure, is to get a PCR testyou have any of these symptoms. You can book a test for free on the NHS website.What to do while you wait for your test results  Dr Habil Khorakiwala, founder and chair of Wockhardt Group, has uploaded a video where he shares six things you can do at home while you wait for your PCR test result. He explains: There are six simple precautions which you may take, and may certainly help in preventing the infection and definitely reduces the severity of symptoms, especially of Omicron.  These are as follows: Step one – gargle with warm salt water Gargle deeply with warm salt water, or a medical mouthwash, three to four times a day. This has been proven in several studies to reduce the saliva viral load for several hours. Step two – steam inhalation Steam inhalation can help ease your symptoms, whether it be a cold or Covid. This is a great trick to soothe and open nasal passages when suffering from a cold or sinus infection. Dr Khorakiwala recommends doing this two to three times a day.  Step three – avoid cold drinks Dr Khorakiwala recommends avoiding drinking cold and chilled beverages. However, itaposs important to stay hydrated, so Dr Khorakiwala recommends drinking hot water frequently. Step four – breathing exercises Dr Khorakiwala recommends practising some form of breathing exercises, such as deep breathing, for at least five minutes a day. Step five – physical exercise Try to do  to  minutes of physical activity daily. Those who arenapost able to do that much should do as much as possible without overexerting themselves. Step six – remember to wear a mask Most importantly, Dr Khorakiwala says we should wear the right-fitting mask properly. He says to only use three-ply surgical masks or N masks. Dr Khorakiwala continued: Avoid common cloth masks and fancy design masks. If necessary, use them only as a double mask over the recommended mask. title: plenty fish monster who used
story: Plenty of Fish monster posed as doctor to control girlfriends le for two yearsCruel and manipulative Carwyn Roberts, , developed a tangled web of lies to control and torment his girlfriend. Using fake email addresses, he convinced her shed been drugged and sexually abused in her own home, and that they had bought a house togetherCarwyn Roberts used fake email addresses to torment and control his girlfriend Image: WALES NEWS SERVICEByJason EvansRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A cruel and manipulative man used fake email addresses and  identities to control his girlfriendaposs le – even convincing her sheaposd been drugged and sexually abused in her own home.Carwyn Roberts, , created fake identities of people in positions of trust, like doctors and lawyers, to spin a web of lies which ranged from the couple buying a house together to convincing the vulnerable woman she was pregnant. He also persuaded her to leave her job at a school by telling her heaposd secured her a new role with the local council. Mold Crown Court heard this week how Roberts subjected his victim to years of torment, which has had a devastating effect on her mental health.Jade Tufail, prosecuting, told the court how Roberts and his victim met on the dating website Plenty of Fish in  and immediately got along. Soon the defendant moved into her flat in Bangor and the relationship was described as amazing with the womanaposs young daughter referring to the defendant as daddy Carwyn. The court heard the womanaposs previous relationship had ended acrimoniously and had left her in a bad way – including engaging in self-harming – and she told her new boyfriend about these issues. The prosecutor said Roberts told the woman he had found out he was was inheriting £, from his grandfatheraposs brother and he would use the money to buy their dream home. The couple went to view houses and settled on one in a new Redrow development in Bangor, and Roberts said his familyaposs solicitors would handle all the legal work. In fact there was no money and there was no family lawyer doing the conveyancing work, and the emails the woman began receiving about the house purchase were being sent by her partner from a bogus account he had set up. This was to be the start of months of cruel deception perpetrated by the defendant. The court heard Roberts then began to tell his partner he was receiving prank calls from people claiming she was being unfaithful and that the solicitor was looking into who was sending them. As the weeks progressed the fake solicitor said he had found out that there were hidden cameras in her flat which had filmed her having sex with men, and he began to quiz her about her sex le. The woman was adamant no such activity had taken place but Roberts, through the bogus solicitor, told her the reason she couldnapost remember what had happened was because she had been drugged before being sexually abused and that the police were now involved. Miss Tufail said while this was going on the defendant created another fake person, this time a woman by the name of Amanda Davies who supposedly worked with him in the local authority, who also began emailing his partner. His victim was persuaded by Amanda Davies to give up her employment in a local school with the promise of job in the council, and Roberts even came home with a work badge in his partneraposs name along with training and induction materials. Again this was all a lie. Then one day the fake council email account contacted the victim to say her partner had been drugged at work in a leisure centre in Caernarfon by an associate of her ex-boyfriend. Over the following days further emails were sent, supposed containing information from a nurse, saying the drugging incident had affected Robertsapos sperm and he would now not be able to have children. The court heard how the victim broke down crying at this news as she had wanted a child with the defendant. The Amanda Davies email account then started giving the woman instructions about having sex with Roberts in order to maximise their chances of conceiving. Meanwhile the charade about the purchase of non-existent house was still continuing and even went so far as the victim, her daughter, and the defendant packing up their possessions ready for the move. Miss Tufail said that by this point the victim had effectively been brainwashed into doing whatever the people in the emails told her to do.The months of lying culminated with Roberts coming home one day with an ultrasound scan showing a pregnancy with twins and telling his partner she was pregnant.This was followed-up by emails from a doctor sent from yet another bogus account he had created. It later transpired the defendant had carried out extensive internet searches in order to obtain a fake ultrasound image. The court heard the victim was confused about the scan and emails from the doctor confirming her pregnancy but the couple went to see her brother to tell the family the happy news. It was the brotheraposs partner who spotted something was amiss with the scan and raised the alarm. The police were contacted and an investigation uncovered the full extent of the defendantaposs deceit. In his first interview the -year-old defendant claimed he had his partner had been duped by somebody  but in his second interview he changed his story and said he, in fact, was the victim of domestic abuse at the hands of his partner. In a statement from the partner which was read to the court she explained the impact the months of lies had had on her. She said she felt ashamed and manipulated and said Roberts had been aware of her vulnerabilities and had exploited every single one of them. Carwyn Grfith Roberts, of Cae Llyn, Llanaelhaearn, Caernarfon, had previously pleaded guilty on the day of trial to engaging in controlling or coercive behaviour in an intimate or family relationship when he appeared in the dock for sentencing. He has no previous convictions. Richard Edwards, for Roberts, said at the time of the offending the defendant was conscious of his own perceived inadequacies and wanted to make himself look better in the eyes of his partner. However matters escalated and – in his clientaposs own words – the lies got bigger and bigger. The barrister said Roberts was taking part in counselling to address the issues in his le and added that he was now in a new relationship with someone who aware of the court case and who was supportive of him. Judge Niclas Parry told Roberts thatthe offending were not so serious people hearing the bizarre facts of the case would be rendered incredulous. He told the defendant he had taken advantage of a vulnerable woman to control her le, adding: Your conduct was as cruel as it was manipulative and despicable. With a % discount for his guilty plea Roberts was sentenced to two years in prison suspended for two years and was ordered to complete a rehabilitation course and  hours of unpaid work. He must also pay £, towards prosecution costs. The defendant was made the subject of a lelong restraining order banning him from contacting his former partner or posting anything about her on social media. Speaking after the hearing Rhian Jones, senior crown prosecutor with the Crown Prosecution Servicein Wales, said: The level of manipulation that Carwyn Roberts exerted on his partner is quite staggering and the effect on her mental health must have been awful. The CPS were able to build a strong case showing the number of fake accounts and emails could be traced back to him, demonstrating he had told lie after lie. The victim can take comfort in knowing that Roberts is now paying for the horrendous ordeal he put her through and we hope this helps her move forward with her le. over tiaras and titles, this latest squabble really is quite unique. The Duke of Sussex’s unprecedented move of threatening to sue the government is both breathtaking and utterly baffling. Those in royal circles have almost universally questioned the play at hand, not only in its nature but equally in execution. True enough, with his background in the military and his position in one of the most famous families in the world – and celebrity lestyle – Prince Harry and his family are arguably high profile targets.  But to suggest he is at a greater risk at home than abroad, where he has chosen to base himself, surely holds very little weight. Indeed the manner of this row seems even more bizarre that it is still being argued two years on from being granted his wish to up and leave his royal role, on the understanding that you can’t have everything you want. This is all before even considering the effect on the Queen, who we are told has been made aware of her grandson’s latest bright idea just as she emerges from one of her most tumultuous periods of recent years. The decision to banish him into the wilderness, arguably a couple of years behind schedule, would not have come easy no matter the depths of his fall from grace. title: professor shares 9 omicron covid
story: Professor shares  Omicron Covid symptoms vaccinated people are likely to experienceWith so many Covid iants having come and gone - each with slight dferences in their symptoms and severity - it can be hard to keep tabs on what to look out for, especially after the altering effects of the vaccine. But an increasing body of data is helping that processAccording to the ZOE Covid App, there are nine common symptoms among vaccinated people Image: Getty ImagesByHarry Thompson:,  Jan | commentsOmicron is is still everywhere and despite very promising signs among the numbers of new cases in the UK, tens of thousands of people continue to pick up the virus every day. The announcement that Plan B measures, which mandated people wearing masks and working from home where possible, will be lted on January  comes as welcome news to many.Because of the still-high numbers, the likelihood of fewer masks, and public places and transport getting a little busier in the coming weeks, it is important to know what to look out for.It is also important for the millions who have been vaccinated to be familiar with Covid symptoms and be able to recognise how they may dfer from symptoms among the unvaccinated. An array of studies has found that Omicron is, on the whole, a milder iant of the virus, with the first official UK report finding that it is between  and % less likely to cause hospitalisation than Delta.Despite this, getting your booster jab remains the best way to protect yourself and those around you from the virus. What symptoms should people look out forthey are vaccinated   Although its findings are not peer-reviewed, the ZOE Covid app study is a useful indicator that pools together the symptoms experienced by people who have tested positive for the virus.Data collected by it has found there are nine symptoms that keep cropping up. Professor Tim Spector, who is one of the key figures behind the project told newsGP : The  million reports submitted via the study’s app have shown that as the virus has evolved, so too have the symptoms it causes. Back in , it quickly became clear that the original and Alpha versions of the coronavirus caused three very common symptoms – cough, fever and loss of smell – as well as at least  others. When Delta appeared, we then noticed a sht in the most frequently reported symptoms. Cold-like symptoms – including a runny nose, sore throat and persistent sneezing – became more common, along with a headache and cough, particularly in people who had been vaccinated. He added: It’s causing symptoms that are much more like a regular cold, particularly in people who’ve been vaccinated, and fewer general systemic symptoms, such as nausea, muscle pains, diarrhoea and skin rashes. This means the nine common symptoms among the vaccinated according to respondents who have added their data to the ZOE Covid app are:Runny noseSore throatSneezing Headache Cough Nausea Muscle painsDiarrhoeaSkin rashThese are of course not necessarily the only things to keep an eye out for but are handy to know aboutyou find yourself developing any of these symptoms. story: Tiny one-bed flat that looks like shed on market for nearly half a million poundsThe home in Hackney, London, backs onto a car park, and has an open plan kitchen, living room with a bathroom downstairs, and a small bedroom on the first floorThe shed-like home is on sale for £, Image: Foxtons ZooplaByAndy CrickKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA tiny one-bed flat has gone on the market for close to half a million pounds even though it looks like a grey shed. The bijoux pad is even located at the bottom of the garden of a terraced house. The property - which backs onto a car park - has an open plan kitchen and living room with a bathroom downstairs. There is a small first floor area where there is a small bedroom. The one-bed flat, in Hackney, north London is just  sqft and has modern decor and a trendy appearance. Have you got an unusual or quirky house for sale  Email us at webnews@mirror It is on sale via Zoopla for £,. The property particulars, marketed with Foxtons, states An amazing one-bedroom flat boasting bright and contemporary accommodation throughout and a quiet location moments from Victoria Park. The property is situated moments from a range of shops and amenities that can be found at the Victoria Park Village while the green expanses of Victoria Park are only a short distance away. Andrew Wilcox, founder and head judge of Shed of the Year likened it to a garden outbuilding. He joked: Not an overpriced beach hut. But a one bed property for sale in London that looks like a fancy shed, £,, £, sq ft  It looks nice for a flat but that price is mad.Dee May agreed and said: I cycle past that place every day on my way home from work! news uk-news tonga-volcano-triggers-mystery-waves-"In pictures: England v TongaByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | comments Scientists have been baffled by mysterious ripples in the Earth’s atmosphere, seemingly triggered by the massive eruption of the underwater Tongan volcano. Satellite data shows unusual atmospheric gravity waves since Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai’s eruption on Saturday which triggered massive ft tsunamis, devastating the island nation. The massive blast also created unusual gravity waves stretching around , kilometres, which have never been seen before, reports Nature. The data was collected by the Atmospheric Infrared Sounderon board a Nasa satellite orbiting the planet. Lars Hoffmann, an atmospheric scientist at the Jülich Supercomputing Centre in Germany, said: “It’s really unique. We have never seen anything like this in the data before.What do you make of the mystery ripples  Have your say in the comment section “This instrument has been operating for something like  years now and we have never seen such nice concentric wave patterns.” The pictures show dozens of concentric circles in the atmosphere which possibly cross the planet several times. Scott Osprey, from the University of Oxford, believes the eruption’s speed could possibly have caused the mystery waves.  One of the possible effects of the waves is the reversal of wind direction which could have an impact in Europe. He added: “This event seems to have been over in minutes, but it was explosive and it’s that impulse that is likely to kick off some strong gravity waves. “We’ll be looking very carefully at how that evolves.”  Hundreds of homes in Tongaaposs smaller outer islands are feared to have been destroyed in the tsunami, with at least three dead. Information on the scale of devastation has come mostly from reconnaissance aircraft as the nation’s airport is smothered by ash and communications have been hampered. Teams from The Red Cross say drinking water has been polluted by salt water from the tsunami and volcanic ash. Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haaposapai has erupted regularly over the past few decades but the impact of Saturdayaposs blast was felt as far away as Japan and the United States. The eruption was also detected by volunteer meteorologists in Hastings, East Sussex. They include alleged drug kingpins, two suspects wanted for murder and underworld armourers.The hit list was released as part of the Most Wanted campaign — a joint initiative between the National Crime Agency, Crimestoppers and Spanish police. Steve Rodhouse, the NCA’s Director General of Operations, said at the launch in Madrid on Wednesday: “Spain is not a safe haven. “We have a brilliant relationship with the country’s ious law enforcement agencies and work together daily to protect the public. “With  offenders arrested in our last fugitives campaign, criminals know we will never give up and we’re never far behind them. He said the Spanish authorities arrested and ed more than  wanted UK fugitives last year. Mr Rodhouse added: “Many of these fugitives will be trying to blend in to the large British communities who have made their homes in Spain, andyou are resident, you may know one of them from your town or village. “Loyalties change over time and we urge anyone with information about these men to help us find them.”The Wanted Dozen Nana OppongOppong, , is wanted by Essex Police for the drive-by murder of grandfather Robert Powell, , who was shot eight times with a mm pistol on  June . story: We both had our drinks spiked on dferent nights out - and we were stealth injectedRhianna Poots and Sara Begic who respectively witnessed and experienced stealth injections and drink spiking are sharing their stories in the hope they can save others from the same experience and Sara Begichope to raise awareness of spiking in Newcastle by sharing their ordeal" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Rhianna-Poots-and-Sara-Begic.jpg" width"" "" Rhianna Pootsand Sara Begichope to raise awareness of spiking in Newcastle by sharing their ordeal Image: Rhianna Poots and Sara BegicBySophie Brownson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Twoteenagerswho claim they had theirdrinks spikedand were injected on two dferent nights out are now describing the terrying ordeals, which left one woman worried about going out.Rhianna Poots and Sara Begic have said they are sharing their stories in the hope they can save others from the same experience.They are sharing their stories in the wake of anepidemic of drink-spiking reportsfrom around the UK in recent months.The majority of the victims to come forward across the UK have been young women, mostly students, but there are also some young men who have reported similar cases. Rhianna was enjoying out in a bar in Newcastle city centre on January  when three of her female friends suddenly became unwell. The Northumbria University student said two of the group, who had been sharing the same drink, started to be violently sick at the venue - with one even needing to be carried out by a bouncer.Speaking to Chronicle Live , -year-old Rhianna said: When we got home their breathing was raspy and their eyes were dilated.  They could all hear what I was saying to them but they couldnapost make sense of it. Rhianna took her friends to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Gateshead as they became increasingly unwell. I called an ambulance as [my friend] Sara [Begic] was especially bad, she said. Her breathing wasnapost right, she was hyperventilating. She wasnapost responding and going in and out of consciousness. They werenapost any ambulances available but they said aposyou need to get her to hospital now.apos All three women underwent tests to see whether they had been spiked. Rhianna said they are still waiting on the results. Sara Begic, , from Durham, believes her drink was spiked during the incident and is now worried about going out again following her ordeal. The Northumbria University law student said: It was horrible. The last thing I remember is sitting with my friends. I knew where I was but I just couldnapost do anything. I couldnapost move my body and the bouncer carried me out. I feel quite unsafe going out now. The group of friends revealed that this isnapost actually the first time they believe they have been spiked while on a night out in the city. One of the students, who did not want to be named, said she was spiked by an injection in her leg on December . She became ill later that night and went to hospital to be checked out the following morning. I felt like I had been possessed and my body felt freezing, she said. It was like I couldn’t physically stop myself from shaking it was probably the worst experience of my le. I don’t feel completely safe going back out again. Rhianna said the friends reported the injection spiking incident to the police but believed that the venue had been unable to help officers because of its poor CCTV footage. As a result, they decided not to report the second incident, which happened at the same venue. However, the friends hope that sharing their story will encourage others to be vigilant when on a night out. Just because people have stopped posting about [spiking] doesnapost mean that it isnapost still happening, Rhianna said. Northumbria Police confirmed that an investigation is ongoing into the reported injection spiking incident and stressed that dedicated officers are on patrol to ensure the city remains a safe place for a night out.A Northumbria Police spokeswoman said: We can confirm we have received a report from a woman concerned she had been spiked with an injection while on a night out in Newcastle on December . “An investigation has been launched and enquiries into this incident are ongoing.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Northumbria PoliceCCTVCCTV footageTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Weve introduced a four-day working week, staff deserve more time offAs a number of UK companies trial employees working a four-day week, in order to measure whether employees are more productive, one Scottish firm has told how it is transforming their livesByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA Scottish distillery has told how they introduced a four-day week for staff in a bid to boost their wellbeing. Owners of The Isle of Barra Distillers decided to shorten the working week in a bid to offer workers more flexibility. The company says it hopes to give its tightly-knit team the opportunity to spend more time with loved ones and spend less time and money commuting. Ahead of the change, which began this month, employees agreed to work the same hours over fewer days - with people opting to work an extra two hours each sht. They have switched up their operation to make the transition work - meaning that orders are no longer being dispatched on a Friday. title: woman cant grieve after council
story: Woman cant grieve after council breaks in to clear her home instead of dead mumsSharon Jackson, , from Stoke-on-Trent, claims the local council switched off her electricity and broke in to her home after her address was mixed up with her late mums, who died at the start of DecemberSharon Jackson says the councils actions have left her unable to grieve for her mums death Image: Stoke SentinelByAimi RedfernPeter DiamondRyan Fahey:,  Jan | comments A woman mourning the death of her mum says a series of blunders made by the local council have left her unable to grieve.Sharon Jackson, , claims council workers forced themselves into her home in Stoke-on-Trent after the death of her mother because they were wrongly told it needed to be cleared.But more distress came later when Sharonaposs gas and electricity were cut off - because the council told British Gas the house was unoccupied. The -year-old says the two major mix-ups have caused a heavy burden of stress, leaving her unable to properly grieve for her late mum, Stoke-on-TrentLive reports. Sharon informed Stoke-on-Trent City council after her beloved motheraposs death on December  and cleared the home.She ed the keys to the authority in a letter that clearly stated the address, she claims.  At the bottom, she included her own address in nearby Dale Avenue and contact details, as requested, in case there were any queries, according to Stoke-on-Trent Live. On December , Sharon was dumbfounded to received a phone call from a friend while she was at work, stating that council workers had forced their way into her home. She said: I was at work when I got a phone call, and I was getting lots of messages, saying the council were breaking into my house. I had to leave work and go home to find they had broken in through the front door. Apparently they had been told that I had done a moonlight flit and the house was empty. There were three vans outside. They had been traipsing though the house. My friend had told they they had the wrong address. By the time I got back, they had gone. The front door handle was all loose because they hadnapost fixed it properly. I felt unsafe in my own house after  years of living there. Sharon, who lives at the property with her -year-old son Reece, contacted Stoke-on-Trent City Council after the mix-up. She said: The woman I spoke to couldnapost apologise enough. They sent me a bunch of flowers and said they would compensate me for the time I lost at work, although I havenapost received that yet.  But it shouldnapost have happened in the first place. I canapost understand how the council could get the address wrong. Thinking that was the end of the matter, Sharon was at home watching TV on January  when her electricity and gas suddenly went off. When she spoke to British Gas, she was told the council had informed them her property was empty. She said: At first I thought it was a power cut but when I looked out I saw it was only my house. I rang British Gas and explained what had happened and they said I had been cut off.  She said they were told by the council in December that the house was empty and the account had been closed. I have had to open a new account to get it sorted out.Sharon, who works at Jackmark Engineering in Longport, says the situation has made what is already an upsetting time even worse.Iaposve not had time to grieve over my mum because Iaposve been so busy sorting out the councilaposs mess. Iaposm a nervous wreck and Iaposm crying all the time.It has been one phone call after another trying to sort out whataposs going on. Iaposve even rung Severn Trent to make sure my water isnapost going to be cut off as well. Iaposm disgusted by the councilaposs ineptitude. A city council spokesman said: Firstly, we would like to extend our deepest sympathies to Sharon and her family for their loss at this very dficult time. We have , council properties and regrettably a genuine administrative mistake was made on this occasion that incorrectly listed the tenancy for ending, which resulted in a lock change being arranged. As part of that process, utility companies are automatically notied at the same time. However, we appreciate this shouldnapost have happened and we have spoken to Sharon and apologised unreservedly. We have also told her we will also cover any financial costs incurred. story: Woman turned le around after chance encounter with cruel stranger on holidayRochelle Hardy was on her first big holiday with her boyfriend Sam to Budapest in  when a group of men made a comment that she was a fat c*** not realising she spoke EnglishAt her heaviest, Rochelle was a size  and weighed nearly  stone Image: FOCUS FEATURESByAnn CusackAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A woman has told of how she turned her le around and lost a six-and-a-half stone after a cruel comment on holiday left her devastated.Rochelle Hardy was on her first big holiday to Budapest in  with her new boyfriend Sam when a strangeraposs comment changed everything. At the time Rochelle was a size  and severely overweight, weighing nearly  stone. Rochelle says: “Actually, those blokes on holiday did me a favour because it was the trigger I needed to turn my le around.” Rochelle grew up in Spain, with English parents, and said she used to get teased at school about her weight. Have you got an inspiring weight loss story  Email webnews@mirror She says: “I went to school in Spain, and the kids called me ‘La Gorda’ which means ‘the fat one.’ My dad would give me spending money every day on the way to school I would pop into the sweet shop with my two euros, filling my bag with sweets. I have a photo of me as a teenager in a bikini, with my hands over my stomach because I am so self-conscious. I wasn’t even hugely overweight at that point, but I hated my body. “My confidence was low, but I didn’t let people know about it. I was pretty tough on the outside.” Rochelle moved back to the UK when she was  and met her current partner, Sam, , in Liverpool. She says: “It sounds like a cliché, but I piled on weight after I met Sam. We were very comfortable, and we ate loads of takeaways and we loved buying pick and mix sweets. Sam was very skinny, but he loved me how I was and paid me lots of compliments.” Rochelle soon weighed -stone and nine pounds and was a dress size . Being just five feet and five inches tall, she was classed as obese. Rochelle and Sam went on their first holiday together to Budapest in , where a group of men made the cruel comment. She says: “There was a group of English blokes nearby and one said: ‘Look at that fat c*** and they all laughed. Obviously, they didn’t know that I was English, but that didn’t excuse it. “I ran into a nearby toilet block and sobbed. “The rest of the holiday was totally miserable for me, and I knew things had to change. That was the turning point.”  When she got back to the UK, Rochelle joined a gym and began eating low-calorie foods - and she lost more than a stone.By October , she joined a Liverpool Slimming World group with a friend and quickly began to lose weight.Rochelle has managed to lose an amazing six and a half stones and she now weighs nine stones and  pounds. Rochelle says she now exercises regularly and eats healthily. Rochelle says: I can happily walk into a room now and not feel like everyone is looking at me, itaposs changed my le. Iaposm not hiding myself away anymore. “That comment in Budapest really upset me but actually they did me a huge favour. That was the turning point for me. story: Young woman with MS facing eviction with her two dogs after gran dies of CovidCaitlin Paul had been living with her gran Elizabeth, , on and off for five years before the pensioner died of coronavirus, days before it killed her son-in-law tooCaitlin Paul is  and has MS. She was her grans main carer Image: Reach plcByKaitlin EastonReporterKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A grieving woman who has MS is facing homelessness after being told she must leave the council home she lived in with her gran before she died of Covid. Caitlin Paul had been living with her gran Elizabeth, , on and off for five years before the pensioner was admitted to hospital with sepsis in February . The -year-old moved into her granaposs Glasgow council flat permanently to look after her beloved dog Buddy while she spent  months recovering in hospital and re-learning basic motor skills.Caitlin became her granaposs main carer when she was discharged from hospital on November ,  and the OAP was given a new wheelchair adapted home by Cadder Housing. The pair planned to put Caitlin on the tenancy agreement so she was officially on documentation but tragically Elizabeth caught Covid just days after being discharged from hospital. She died a short time later before the tenancy documents could be updated. Are you facing eviction unfairly  Email webnews@mirror Caitlin, who suffers from MS, will be evicted from the house tomorrow and has nowhere to go, leaving her homeless with two dogs.She told the Daily Record : Me and my gran were really close so I stayed with her all the time. Last year she was unwell and had sepsis so I had to phone an ambulance and she was taken into hospital.We got a call saying she wouldnapost make it through the night and then another call the night after that, but she did. She was in hospital for  months and lost all her mobility. She had to re-learn how to feed herself but she did - she was amazing.  She was a tenant in a flat with Cadder Housing but they offered her a specially adapted home when she was in hospital. I got the house ready for her coming home, and decorated it so it was nice and fresh. We had lots of balloons up for the day she got out of hospital. I even had a sausage sandwich ready for her as she hadnapost had one in ages.The family had a small gathering to welcome Elizabeth into her new home but tragically days later Elizabeth, Caitlin, her mum Deborah, auntie Jacqui, sister Beth and uncle George, all tested positive for coronavirus. Caitlin said: She got out of hospital and then we caught Covid three days later. My gran was ok at first, but a few nights later she went downhill and I had to phone an ambulance. She didnapost want to go into hospital. She was really upset and scared she wouldnapost get back out. But it was the best place for her as she needed oxygen. On Monday, November  my gran was told she was getting on Tuesday and an ambulance had been arranged to bring her home. That night she took a turn for the worst. The hospital called and told me to go up, but when I arrived to see her she wasnapost herself. We just had to sit with her until she died.  Elizabeth died in the early hours of Tuesday November  at Glasgow Royal Infirmary after her lung collapsed due to Covid complications. Tragedy struck again when Caitlinaposs uncle George - Elizabethaposs son-in-law - died from coronavirus in the same hospital on November  just four days later. The devastated family were left to plan two funerals and fork out thousands of pounds. Caitlin began to fear for her future as she was never added to her granaposs tenancy agreement. Less than three weeks after her granaposs sudden death, she met with Cadder Housing and on December  she was told their hands were tied and she was given three weeks to evict the property.  Caitlin was then admitted to hospital with MS and Cadder gave her an extension until January . I completely understand Iaposm not on the tenancy agreement but we never thought anything like this would happen, Caitlin said. I never wanted to stay here permanently, as Iaposm not in a wheelchair and the house could go to someone  who needs it. I only wanted to stay here until I had somewhere  to go. They told me to contact Shelter Scotland and said they had been trying to get me temporary accommodation through the council. My MS has got worse with the stress and so has my mental health. I havenapost even had time to grieve the loss of my gran and my uncle. I felt like they could have at least said you can stay until you find somewhere  to go. They didnapost even offer to help with storage. title: woman travelled 500 miles take
story: Woman travelled  miles to take UKs easiest driving test and failedConstance Kampfner travelled  miles, from London to the Isle of Mull in search of the UKs easiest driving test - but sadly she failed againConstance wanted to give herself the best chance of passing her test Image: PAByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments Regardless of whether you passed on your first go, or youaposre one of the unlucky ones who took six attempts - youaposve got to admit, driving tests are hard.And, while every driving test is required to feature a host of dferent things, they obviously dfer depending on which part of the country youaposre taking it in. So, when one woman failed her first driving test in her native London, instead of re-booking locally, she decided to travel approximately  miles to the Isle of Mull, just off the west coast of Scotland, in search of the UKaposs aposeasiestapos test. Constance Kampfner spent  hours travelling north, by car and ferry, having handpicked the test route after discovering it only consisted of one roundabout her biggest fear. However, on arrival, she struggled to find a single driving instructor willing to take her for her test, forcing her to turn to Facebook in desperation. I was determined I would pass my driving test the second time - I simply needed to optimise my chances. A quick Google search told me where I needed to go, the Isle of Mull. I booked for the earliest available date, in mid-December, she told The Times. For their lessons residents tend to head to Oban on the mainland, where the ferry to the island departs from. None of the instructors I got hold of fancied the trip, each warning me of high chances that my crossing would be cancelled in bad weather. I took to Facebook, where local paramedic Mairi took pity and offered her blue Mini.Constance was feeling confident, especially after learning Mullaposs single roundabout would not feature on her test and there was nowhere to parallel park - not to mention the stunning local scenery which glistened under the winter sun. When they got back onto the mainland, the test instructor told her: I don’t like to talk about people who fail their tests. Think of it as just not passing. Better luck next time, Constance.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. extent of the destruction that has been wrought on the islands with hundreds of homes washed away.At least three people have been killed from the volcanic eruption and tsunami that struck last Saturday which the Tonga government has called an unprecedented disaster.Photos show shocked people looking at the horror caused with homes and livelihoods destroyed. Waves reaching up to  metres hit the outer Haaposapia island group, destroying all of the houses on the island of Mango, as well as the west coast of Tongaaposs main island, Tongatapu, the prime ministeraposs office said. In Kanokupolu village on the island of Tongatapu locals have been pictured staring at trees that have been felled, buildings in ruins and everything coated in black ash. James Garvin, chief scientist at NASAaposs Goddard Space Flight Center, said the force of the eruption was estimated to be equivalent to five to  megatons of TNT, an explosive force more than  times the nuclear bomb dropped by the United States on Hiroshima, Japan, at the end of World War Two. The blast was heard as far away as Alaska and was probably one of the loudest events to occur on Earth in over a century, according to Michael Poland, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey.This might be the loudest eruption since [the eruption of the Indonesian volcano] Krakatau in , Poland told NPR. That massive th-century eruption killed thousands and released so much ash that it cast much of the region into darkness. Hunga Tonga-Hunga Haaposapai was completely destroyed by Saturdayaposs explosion, says Dan Slayback, a research scientist for NASAaposs Goddard, as well as Science Systems and Applications Inc. Slayback says the blast was so massive it even appears to have taken chunks out of the older islands nearby. They werenapost ash — they were solid rock, blown to bits, he says. It was quite amazing to see that happen.  With its airport smothered by volcanic ash and communications badly hampered by the severing of an undersea cable, information on the scale of the devastation has mostly come from reconnaissance aircraft. Planes sent from New Zealand show the damage from the air with images of the inundation caused by tsunami on the western coast of the main island of Tongatapu.  A dficult humanitarian aid effort is now under way to help the survivors from the disaster. The Red Cross said its teams in Tonga had confirmed that salt water from the tsunami and volcanic ash were polluting the drinking water relied on by tens of thousands of people. Securing access to safe drinking water is a critical immediate priority... as there is a mounting risk of diseases such as cholera and diarrhoea, Katie Greenwood, the Pacic head of delegation for the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, said in a statement. news world-news hairdresser-shares-horric-lice-infestation-"Hairdresser shows lice infestation in child’s hairByRia NewmanLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan A hairdresser shared a harrowing video of a child who had to have her head shaved because it was infested with lice.Rachel Maroun, , from Sydney, Australia, works as a head lice technician and shares clips of her most severe cases online.Her recent clip went viral on TikTok and led to the little girl being taken away by Child Protective Services . “I could tell the lice were draining more than just her blood, she looked sick and was covered in lice bites over her body, she said. Rachel told how the girl, who she estimates was aged between six and seven, came in with a headscarf on and showed her the infestation which was the worst Rachel had ever seen. The child was later taken to hospital and needed to have her head shaved. “She was very quiet and showed me how the lice were biting down her neck and back, since there was little to no space for them to crawl freely in her hair,” Rachel said. “Immediately when I saw her I knew something was wrong and that this would be the biggest case of lice I’ve had to face. “I’m used to extreme lice infestations but was definitely not prepared for what I saw. “I was told that the child had been dealing with the lice for several months and that treatments were being applied. “But my professional opinion is that this was an extended lice case where nothing was being done to combat it. The hairdresser said she could tell that the girlaposs hair had not been brushed in months and had tangled into a deep dreadlock matting that would have been impossible to treat with lice solution. This is sadly the result of child neglect,” she continued. It takes a very long time for lice to reach the point of severe infestation. It takes an even longer amount of time for hair to go that matted. In the video, which Rachel shared with her three million followers, the hairdresser films the child’s hair which can be seen crawling with lice. She said: “This poor child has obviously had lice for a very long time. Her hair has not been brushed in ages and has turned into one big ball of lice and knots, which meant that I called Child Protective Services right away.” Showing a clip of her usual method used on a previous client, Rachel wets the hair and applies a conditioning treatment before combing through the hair. Using glass, she “pops” the lice, pressing down to kill them. Sadly, this was not an option for the child and would have been too painful due to the matted condition of her hair. “In usual cases, it’s just a matter of combing through the hair section by section and popping the lice but I didn’t want to put a metal comb anywhere near this poor baby’s hair, Rachel said. “You can even see the lice were drinking blood out of her forehead. This broke my heart to see but I’m really glad she’s okay now.” The post went viral, racking up . million likes and being viewed  million times. One person commented: “Watching her wipe her tears made me have to do the same thing. I’m so sad for her but glad to hear she is safe.” Another user said: “I’m so so thankful that you stood up for her and protected her. Some users commented there was “no excuse” for the girl’s condition, while other people said their heads were itchy after watching the footage. After removing the lice infestation, Rachel updated her followers to explain the child had been picked up by CPS and was taken to hospital. “Although it was not the finished result anyone was hoping for, I know she feels a whole lot better with a fresh start so her scalp can start to heal, she said. Filming the hair for a follow-up post, Rachel explained the child’s hair had been detaching from the scalp. She says: “This left no space for the lice to move anywhere so they had to go on her hands and her neck to drink blood out of her body like that.” “Also there was a smell that leads me to believe there was some kind of mould in the matting here. “It’s very rare I see cases like this but it always breaks my heart.” Rachel also added that the stigma surrounding head lice is a big contributing factor to the spread of lice, as well as a “lack of education” and “embarrassment”. title: stunning pic shows sahara desert
story: Sahara desert blanketed in rare snowfall as temperatures plunge to -CThe desert has gone through temperature and moisture changes over the past few hundred thousand years, but snow rarely occurs because there is not usually enough water in the air for itThe Sahara Desert is covered in snow Image: Karim Bouchetta Bav MediaByLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Stunning images of sand dunes in the Sahara desert covered in snow have been captured by a photographer.The desert is more commonly known for its hot and dry climate so this incredible sight is very rare occurence. Temperatures had plummeted to -C when Karim Bouchetata took the photos on Tuesday near the town of Ain Sefra in northwest Algeria yesterday.The area has seen snow before due to it being surrounded by the Atlas Mountains and , metres above sea level.But the phenomenon is still rare as it has seen snow just five times in the last  years - in , ,  and .  The ice created stunning patterns in the sand but there possible wasnapost enough of the white stuff to build a lesize snowman or an igloo. The Sahara Desert covers most of Northern Africa and Ain Sefra is known as ‘The Gateway to the Desert’. The desert has gone through temperature and moisture changes over the past few hundred thousand years, but snow rarely occurs because there is not usually enough water in the air for it despite it being able to get very cold at night.  The desert is much hotter with an average temperature during the day a majority of the time with the mercury hitting C. It has a heat record of more than C. Katim also captured pictures of the Sahara Desert covered in snow in January last year.  Sheep and camels were also seen standing on the snowy dunes as temperatures dipped to -C. In  snow fell in the area that was settled children made snowmen and even sledged on the sand dunes. Two years later the desert was covered in  inches deep snow after a freak winter storm - the second showing of the white stuff for  years. Karim said at the time: We were really surprised when we woke up to see snow again.
